article.title: Hydrodynamic approach to electronic transport in graphene

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the temperature dependence of conductivity in suspended graphene at the Dirac point. What is the dominant scattering mechanism at **intermediate** temperatures?
Figure 2 illustrates the electron and hole currents in a finite graphene sample. What causes the difference in current distribution between the bulk and the edges?
choices: Different mobilities of electrons and holes
Recombination processes at the sample edges
Influence of the magnetic field on charge carriers

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 presents the magnetoresistance of bilayer graphene at the charge neutrality point. What theoretical framework best describes the observed linear magnetoresistance?
Figure 4 depicts the phenomenon of giant magnetodrag in graphene. What is the primary mechanism responsible for the observed negative magnetodrag at charge neutrality?
choices: Direct electron tunneling between the graphene layers
Lateral quasiparticle flow induced by the magnetic field
Spin-orbit coupling between the two graphene layers

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 6 illustrates the concept of a hot spot in graphene. What is the nature of the stable, soliton-like solution formed in the absence of dissipation?
choices: Composite energy and charge density profile
Localized region of high chemical potential
